abstract.p: Ken Johnson reviews Pop-Conceptual art by Peter Gould at Kagan Martos gallery (S)

block.p: As much as it is a style, Pop Art is for contemporary artists a tool for investigating and analyzing modern culture. Peter Gould, a young Pop-Conceptualist having his first solo exhibition in New York, focuses on the place of nature in our pervasively artificial world.

As much as it is a style, Pop Art is for contemporary artists a tool for investigating and analyzing modern culture. Peter Gould, a young Pop-Conceptualist having his first solo exhibition in New York, focuses on the place of nature in our pervasively artificial world.

In a series called ''Famous Restaurants,'' deadpan black-and-white photographs mounted on Formica panels document the landscaping around fast-food establishments like Burger King and Pizza Hut. These images of miniature parks with gravel paths, neatly groomed shrubbery and picnic tables speak to a longing for pastoral experience diametrically opposed to the industrialized consumption that the fast-food restaurant actually promotes.

Extending his project wittily into sculpture, Mr. Gould presents two small, parklike installations in which grass is represented by green Formica and bushes by free-standing silhouettes cut from thin panels and painted shades of green. Stacked red bricks provide architectural framing. These cartoonlike abstractions of the modern corporate oasis -- itself an abstraction of the centuries-old dream of Eden -- are quietly funny and, because they tap into our romantic yearnings for oneness with nature, oddly touching.
